 Technical Annex Page 2 of 34 A. BACKGROUND Agriculture in the Economy 1 . Prior to the civil war, Bosnia and Herzegovina (BH) had a population of about 4.4 million people, of whom some 68 percent or 3.0 million were of employable age (15-64). Of these about 2 percent were employed by the organized agricultural sector while a further 16 percent were private sector farmers or farm workers. Per capita income for BH which had grown at over 5 percent p.a. in the 1970s and 2 percent p.a. in the first half of the 1980s has declined since 1986 and in 1991 was of the order of US$1,900. Agriculture's performance was much less impressive than that of the economy as a whole in the 1970s (annual growth of 0.6 percent compared with 5.2 percent), but it grew at 3.6 percent p.a. in the first half of the 1980s compared with 1.9 percent p.a. for the whole economy and only fell moderately (by an average of 1.1 percent p.a.) between 1986 and 1990. Forestry, which had grown by about 2 percent p.a. from 1971 to 1986 has fallen sharply over the 1986-1990 period. In 1990, agriculture's share of GSP' comprised 14 percent and that of forestry, 2 percent (see table below). Overall, BH was a net 'importer' of temperate agricultural products. The net 'export' of livestock products, particularly milk to the Dalmatian coast, would have been outweighed by 'imports' of grains, and protein meals, as well as products for human consumption. Because BH is essentially rural, with only 20 percent of the population living in the 10 largest towns prior to the war, agriculture impacts on a large proportion of households. The 1981 census indicated that there were some 540,000 farm households. Thus, at that time, over half of all households were agricultural. It is likely that until 1991, the situation was broadly similar. 3.  Technical Annex Paae 3 of 34 livestock, and about a quarter of the intensive livestock. Forestry, on the other hand is largely socially owned. Over three quarters of the forest area, 88 percent of the timber stocks, 88 percent of the annual growth increment and about 90 percent of the offtake are within the social sector. Until the late 1980s, agro-industry of any significant scale was entirely a social sector business. Only on-farm processing such as kitchen-scale production of meat and milk products, or local slaughtering could have been categorized as private. 4. Largely as a result of the war, BH's overall GSP and agriculture and forestry sector performance have all deteriorated sharply. No reliable measures of sectoral output are available; however, since industrial GSP fell more precipitously, agriculture's importance within the economy as a whole may have increased. Shortly prior to the war, measures were taken to liberalize the economy by removing restrictions on land ownership and on the number of persons which could be employed by private firms. Additionally, some measures had also been taken to privatize the social sector units. Because of the war situation, these measures have not yet had a significant effect on private sector expansion in agriculture and agro-industries. Agricultural Resources and Performance 5. Land. BH comprises some 20 percent of the land area of former Yugoslavia. About half (2.5 million ha) of its total area of 5.11 million ha is agricultural land and a further 45 percent (2.3 million ha) is forest. Of the agricultural land, just over 1 million ha are arable fields and gardens, about 100,000 ha are orchards and vineyards, some 470,000 ha are meadows and 930,000 ha are pastures, mainly in mountain regions. The quality of land in BH is varied. Although some of it, around Banja Luka and along the Sava River is relatively flat, good quality arable land, most is in hilly areas where there is cultivation in the valley bottoms and grazing on the hillsides. Much of BH is mountainous with peaks rising to nearly 2,400 m. However, a significant part of this mountainous land is classified as forest rather than agricultural area. In general, the better quality arable land is in regions of the Republika Srpska. 6. Climate. BH is between 42 and 45 degrees North, roughly at the same latitude as Central Italy. Mostly, its climate can be classified as continental and is affected by altitude, being particularly harsh in the iniand mountain areas where the topography is rugged. Annual average rainfall in BH varies depend-ng on altitude, and proximity to the coast. In central Bosnia, it is typically between 800 mm and 1,000 mm per year and distributed fairly evenly; in winter, much of the precipitation is as snow. Towards the coast, however, the climate is more mediterranean with very limited summer rainfall, but wet winters - Mostar has annual rainfall of about 1,500 mm, but less than 200 mm from June through September. Temperatures in the center of Bosnia typically average 22C in July and around OC in January; in Mostar however, they are higher at about 25C degrees in July and 5C in January. The hot continental summers mean that parts of the country, particularly the south west, would benefit from irrigation, although overall the amount of irrigation currently used is small. Drainage and flood protection are important issues along the Sava River. 7. Land ownership in BH had previously been largely private with about 94 percent of agricultural land belonging to individuals2. As a result of the war and considerable movement of refugees, the issue of land ownership is critical within an agricultural development strategy in the short- and medium-term. 2 The pasture area which accounts for some 37 percent of private land is thought not to be generally owned by individual farmers but rather to belong to farmers communally.

While no direct evidence on fragmentation in BH is available from the literature, surveys in former Yugoslavia as a whole and observations in the neighboring Macedonia and Serbia suggest that the average farm may well have about 10 disparate parcels of land. This fragmentation is particularly constraining in the flatter areas where mechanization would otherwise be possible. In the hill areas, farm size is typically larger than in the plains and units are more often consolidated. The substantial movement of population which has taken place during mnore than three years of war has caused that in many areas, people who are occupying land are not those with legal title to it. Estimates indicate that, for the time being, up to one third of the farmers with land title no longer occupy their own land. 8. Private farming systems in BH are largely mixed. In 1981, there were 370,000 full time workers on the 233,000 private farms with workers - about one worker per three hectares of cropped land. Generally, low output mixed farming systems are followed; small areas of cereals and other crops are produced as well as vegetables and fruit (principally plums and apples) for the household. Most farms tend to have some livestock also, cattle being the most widely held type. Indeed, in 1981 more than seventy percent of all private farms had at least one cow. Additionally, over half of all farms exceeding 3 ha in size, kept pigs. Sheep were less widely owned with only 20 percent of farmers owning any sheep at all, but among these, some 24,000 farmers (about 5 percent of all farms) had at least 20 head. SubFtantial sheep flocks are most common in areas with access to communal mountain pasture. Aericultural services. The organization of agricultural services at the central, Federation, canton and municipal levels is in a state of transition. The former structure, with agriculture as part of the Ministry of Energy and Industry, changed as of February 1, 1996, when a new Ministry of Agriculture, Water Management and Forestry at the Federation was created. The intention is to also form departments with the same sector responsibilities at the Canton level. 14. Before the war there were some 1,200 professional agriculturalists (including animal husbandry) in BH; details of the present situation are not yet available. The available professional agricultural staff is estimated at only about 250. Of these only a few are at the central and Canton levels, with the bulk of the agricultural staff employed at the municipal level. Municipal agricultural staff, typically consisting of about 3-5 specialists in agriculture and livestock development, are working in the office of the Mayor. In view of the difficult employment situation in the industrial sector, agriculture is given high priority in the work program of the municipalities. Agricultural extension to private farmers is not yet operational. The Municipal agricultural staff is providing advice to farmers, but not in a planned and structured manner. Agricultural research is to be carried out in Agricultural Institutes, but due to staff and funding shortage and destruction of facilities, little research is presently being undertaken. Farm Mechanization 15. No recent data is available on the current level of mechanization on private farms in BH, since statistics had been published on tractors held on private farms but ceased being collected in 1991. Based on 1991 fligures of about 60,000 two-axle tractors and some 32,000 motor-cultivators and single-axle tractois (or about one tractor per 17 ha of cultivated land), it is likely that in the aggregate the degree of tractorization in BH was adequate prior to the war. For a 40 hp standard tractor, an area of 12 to 15 ha in hilly areas and up to 30 ha in flat land was considered appropriate. The major part of the farmland in BH is on slopes, only about 20 percent of the farmland is on flat areas. 16. More than 97 percent of tractors were on private farms (see table below). Because of the small farm size structure, however, there were still likely to be many farmers who did not have access to mechanical equipment; this could account for the high horse population then (1 horse per 9 ha of cropped arable land). The main aggregate mechanization problem previously observed within Former Yugoslavia was the shortage of specialist equipment at the farm level. 17. The other main problem was the very small farm size and the difficulty farmers have in
 Technical Annex Page 7 of 34 establishing sound commercial arrangements for tractor sharing/hire, particularly on mixed farms where daily (but limited) use of tractors is the norm. Effective systems of contracting agricultural services or hiring equipment need to be developed to allow individual farmers access to suitable seeders, planters, mowers, sprayers, harvesting equipment etc., without having to invest themselves. As a positive step towards more efficient agricultural production, the previous restriction on the maximum farm size of 15 ha has been lifted. Hence, it can be expected that more suitable, larger farm structures would emerge in the medium term, especially as soon as alternative sources of household income become available and part-time farmers would decide to lease or sell their land to others. The war has affected the major part of the existing farm equipment. An estimated 70-80 percent of the tractors and implements including single-axle tractors and combine harvesters has been destroyed or stolen. Of the remaining equipment, only about 50-70 percent is in working condition due to maintenance problems and lack of spare parts in the war situation. The equipment is mostly aged and in many cases major rehabilitation work will not solve the mechanization problem in the medium term. The reliability and quality of work of this equipment is not adequate. 19. It is estimated that in many areas up to 30 percent of the arable land is not cultivated. The main reason given by farmers for that circumstance is the shortage of farm equipment, ranking ahead of other factors such as the presence of land mines, or issues of disputed land ownership. Lack of combine harvesters has led to delayed harvests and low crop yields, and the provision of combine harvesters is therefore considered as high priority. Lack of farm equipment is also responsible for insufficient land preparation and planting, especially for cereal crops and potatoes. The remaining farmers are generally cultivating those areas where they presently live, provided they have the inputs and equipment to do so. With the few remaining farm machines, a system of private contracting of machinery service appears to
 Technical Annex Page 8 of 34 be developing gradually, which will make possible the economic use of machines even with BH's small farm sizes. 20. A high percentage of the rural population, which was formerly employed in industrial enterprises and was running srnall farms of 0.1 - 3 ha as a part-time business, are now left to survive from the returns of their farm land. These farmers are heavily affected by the loss or destruction of their farm equipment, which in most cases were motor-cultivators or single-axle tractors. The horse population has also been heavily reduced since January 1992, by an estimated 36 percent, from 90,000 to 58,000. The remaining horses are mainly used for transport. 21. A high percentage of the agricultural land is dedicated to forage production for livestock. In some areas, over 50 percent of the arable land is used for artificial meadows, maize or rape production for forage purposes. The productivity in forage production is extremely low. Of 5 to 7 possible cuts on the artificial meadows, only 2 cuts are actually performed. This not only translates into lower yields but also results in poor quality of the hay. Most of the hay harvest is done by hand, with an output of no more than 0.3 ha/day. This compares to an output with a motorized single-axle mower of about 2.7 ha/day. Most of the maize and rape as well as the grass grown at present cannot be used for the production of silage because of lack of shredders. Better quality forage for animals is urgently required to enable the rehabilitation of the livestock. This bottleneck towards animal feeding requires urgent addressing. There are indications that the reproduction rate of cattle suffers due to insufficient alimentation. 22. While the availability of spare parts and workshop services is in general not satisfying, there are regional differences. For the present stock of machinery, no inventory or listing of required spare parts exists. There is also uncertainty whether some of the required parts are still in production because much of the existing equipment is outdated. Spare parts were formerly distributed on a centralized basis, and new channels of distribution have to be developed. Dealers for agricultural equipment and spare parts are already emerging, and they will require training for new machines and technology, to be provided by the respective machinery suppliers. As an alternative to commercial farm equipment dealers, farmer cooperatives, base on the initiative of private individual farmers, are also emerging. These cooperatives are mainly input supply and output marketing associations, and they represent an excellent potential to develop as a dealer network for farm equipment. Livestock Production 23. Livestock are important in BH, particularly cattle and sheep. While the area of main crops grown in BH only represented 12 percent of that in the former Yugoslavia, its herd of breeding cows and of breeding sheep amounted to 25 percent and 18 percent respectively of the former national totals. The table below indicates the numbers of livestock in BH and the proportion held in the private and socialist sectors. The vast majority are in the private sector (see table below). Only with intensive livestock, especially poultry (37 percent) and pigs (19 percent) did the socialist sector control a significant proportion of the herd. 24. Technical performance from livestock is quite poor and was generally below that in other parts of the former Yugoslavia except in the case of sheep meat production. For example, the milk produced per cow per year, which is a key dairying performance indicator, is under 1,500 liters in BH and only 83 percent of the average for the former Yugoslavia. This is only about one third of that achieved by

Similarly, with one of the key indicators for pigs - number slaughtered per sow per year, the BH performance of 10.4 is 93 percent of that of the former Yugoslavia and only about 50 percent of that achieved on successful western European farms. Poor livestock performance is due to limited availability of feed as well as the almost complete lack of extension service to private farmers; professional agricultural services were devoted to large-scale farms in the socially- owned sector on which extensive management systems were practiced and where reasonable yields, regardless of economic considerations, were obtained. Cattle husbandrv. The pre-war cattle population of BH of some 950,000 head were largely maintained by private farmers. These were kept on small-holdings and individual herd sizes were small,
 Technical Annex Page 10 of 34 frequently of less than six heads. Sinimental and Brown Swiss dual purpose type cattle were kept for the production of meat and milk. During the summer months, cattle graze on natural and in some cases improved sown pastures, but the long winter requires their housing for six months of the year. Winter feeding is on locally conserved hay which is harvested late and, as a result, of poor digestibility and quality. Due to the necessity to keep as many productive cattle on the premises as possible, calves are sold at a young age for veal, only the minimal number of female calves being kept as replacements. Some 4 percent of the cattle population were maintained on State farms. These institutions kept Holstein- Friesian type cows, largely on intensive zero grazing systems, typically making corn silage as the maintenance ration and feeding concentrates for production. A limited number of Holstein-Friesian cattle are also kept by the private sector. 27. Milk is mostly sold privately, also to milk factories at Mostar, Tuzla and Zenica which are operating at low levels of capacity at the present time. Thriving peri-urban dairy industry is reported surrounding Sarajevo, including a State farm. Simmental cattle are considered very suitable for the areas around Tuzla, Zenica and north towards Tesanj, with Brown Swiss being more popular in the areas of Travnik, Bugojno and Kupres. The husbandry standards to achieve good performance from Holstein- Friesian cows and the demand for a dual purpose breed suggest that importation of this breed in large numbers is inadvisable at the present time. 28. Sheep husbandry. Prior to the war, the sheep population of BH is estimated at 1.3 million. Sheep fulfil a triple purpose role producing milk for cheese making, a light yield of coarse wool, and meat. Production systems are typified by the system adopted for the Pramnenka breed in the areas of Travnik, Bugojno and Kupres. During the winter months flocks are maintained on the lowland pasture of valley bottoms with limited additional feeding of poor quality hay. Multiple births are rare and the occasional twins that are born are usually fostered on to ewes that have lost their lamb. However, Pramenka breeders in the Herzegovina region report that strains of the breed may lamb twice a year. In this area, limited selection, controlled breeding and hormonal treatments are under investigation aiming to produce up to six lambs in a two year period. Milk production is approximately 150 kg per lactation, yielding 15 kg of cheese. Flocks, which are entirely in the hands of private owners, range in size from 20, to as large as 1,000 head. The breed is extremely hardy and uniquely adapted to the demanding production environment. The replacement or dilution of this breed type could be detrimental to the use of this harsh production environment. 29. For example, information from authorities in Travnik details a 1992 population of 50,000 Vlasicka Pramenka3 which now equals about 20,000 only. Prior to the immediate past, this decline is attributed to the nationalization of winter valley grazing land for industrial development, housing and for cultivation. To combat this, transport of sheep flocks to winter grazing areas as far away as Slovenia by rail and road transport, had been practiced in the past. This opportunity has now been lost by recent political events. An Association of Private Farmers in Travnik represents 158 members, primarily sheep farmers who own flocks ranging from 40 - 1,000 heads. The Association provides credit, advice and a limited range of inputs. It is also marketing wool, cheese and milk. Over the war, members' flocks have been reduced from 50,000 to 10,000 and many of the grazing areas are known to be heavily mined. 30. The Association of Private Farmers in Travnik represents a potential focus for both the expansion and improvement of the Pramenka breed. To allow breed expansion, the Association is prepared to buy better quality female lambs and superior ram lambs, to distribute to small flock owners and to new farmers. Shepherding is essentially a family occupation, with younger men taking the flock to the mountains for summer grazing and older family members tending the lowl'and holding. The areas of Travnik, Bugojno and Kupres have suffered heavy war damage and are target areas for assistance of this kind. 31. Goat husbandry. The pre-war goat population is estimated at 95,000. In 1951, the goat populations in various regions were, however, considerably larger; 250,000 has been cited as the population for the Travnik region alone. In 1951, an edict was issued by the Government of the former Yugoslavia prohibiting the keeping of goats. At the time this was probably considered a conservation measure to conserve forestry stocks. It is now more widely accepted that the potential of correctly managed goat flocks is substantial. There seems no prejudice about the consumption of goat meat and the recognition of the value of goat milk is increasing. Private farmers have expressed interest in goat production and the re-establishment of goat flocks is occurring. Individual flocks of up to 200 goats are managed commercially in the Herzegovina region. 32. Goat husbandry would be complementary to cattle and sheep husbandry. The project is designed to meet about 10 percent of the urgent needs to re-install farm power and provide livestock breeding material and veterinary support to make up for war damage. The resulting benefits of these activities refer both to a return to productive use of land currently not in production, and to increased output on land already in production. In addition to incremental farm and food output, the project would generate employment and income for the rural population. This would also and particularly benefit demobilized soldiers and former industrial, now unemployed workers, through increased

The 750 two-axle tractors and 3,700 motor- cultivators are likely to result in incremental cultivation of some 35,000 ha (20 ha per tractor and 5 ha per motor-cultivator). The increase in food crops (mainly cereals and potatoes) is estimated at some 100- 120,000 tons of grains and some 20,000 tons of potatoes. Incremental production as a result of the livestock component would consist of additional milk, cheese, meat, and, to a lesser extent, wool. doc.repnme: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency Farm Reconstruction Project
doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Emergency Farm Reconstruction Project are to jump-start agricultural production, improve food security, and create employment and income for the war-affected rural population including returning displaced persons. The project comprises the following components: (a) farm mechanization will provide motor-cultivators and tractors, replacement of lost tractors, replacement of selected combine harvesters, and provision of related technical assistance and training; (b) livestock production will assist in rebuilding the national herds for milk and meat production, through the import of cattle, goats and sheep; (c) animal health services will help strengthen veterinary services by equipping and rebuilding private veterinary stations, and provide equipment; and (d) project implementation will assist with start-up and will implement the project through provision of equipment, technical assistance, training and studies, and through financing of incremental recurrent expenditures.
